title: Portuguese police chief who won legal battle with Madeleine McCann's parents 'penning second book over disappearance'
text:
News Portuguese police chief who won legal battle with Madeleine McCann's parents 'penning second book over disappearance' Goncalo Amaral won a long-running legal battle with Kate and Gerry McCann earlier this week when Portugal's highest court threw out the parents' libel case Share Goncalo Amaral won a legal battle with the McCanns (Photo: AFP) Share Get daily   
The Portuguese police chief who won a legal battle with Madeleine McCann's parents over a controversial book about her disappearance is reportedly penning a follow-up. 
Goncalo Amaral won a long-running legal battle with Kate and Gerry McCann earlier this week when Portugal's highest court threw out the parents' libel case against the detective. 
The McCanns had won around £400,000 in compensation over claims they were implicated in their daughter's appearance but the decision was overturned following an appeal. 
The original book was published in 2008 and judges ruled Mr Amaral's 'exercise of his freedom of expression was not considered abusive' and 'was within admissible limits in a democratic and open society, which excludes the illegality of possible damage to the honour of the McCanns.' Read More Kate and Gerry McCann spoke of their disappointment over the ruling (Photo: Getty) The police chief is now said to be penning a second book (Photo: AFP) 
Now the Sunday Express reports is putting the finishing touches on his second book and looking for a publisher. 
A friend of the author told the paper: "Goncalo took no great pleasure from the court case because he fully expected to win. For him these battles in the courts are important because they protect freedom of expression. 
"He could only afford to pay the legal bills thanks to donations, mainly from people in Britain, who have given more than £50,000. With the support in Britain he obviously thinks his second book on the case would sell well if translated into English and he is actively looking for a publisher. 
"He would also ask any publisher if they would be interested in publishing his first book in English." Read More Madeleine McCann vanished almost 10 years ago (Photo: Find Madeleine Campaign/PA) The three-year-old vanished from a hotel in Praia Da Luz (Photo: Philip Coburn / Daily Mirror) 
The McCanns are understood to be prepared to sue if the book is sold in the UK. 
Mr Amaral was in charge of the investigation when three-year-old Madeleine, then went missing from the apartment the McCanns were staying in in Praia da Luz as Kate and Gerry ate dinner with friends. 
The judges' official ruling is set to be published later this week. 
The McCanns said in a statement: "What we have been told by our lawyers is obviously extremely disappointing. 
"It is eight years since we brought the action and in that time the landscape has dramatically changed, namely there is now a joint Metropolitan Police-Policia Judiciaria investigation which is what we've always wanted. 
"The police in both countries continue to work on the basis that there is no evidence that Madeleine has come to physical harm. 
"We will, of course, be discussing the implications of the Supreme Court ruling with our lawyers in due course." Like us on Facebook
